{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3474910,"name":"Ethan Grieshop","username":"CakeDeer6","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cakedeer6/{size}/264680_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-08T02:44:13.374Z","cooked":"

I’m trying to use the wpimath trajectory class to find an efficient path for the bot to travel on the fly. When I generate a path, it gives me a trajectory object, containing a bunch of states. How am I supposed to use these states to tell the swerve modules what to do? The states seem to only have scalar properties (i.e. magnitude of acceleration, speed, etc) so I don’t know how to calculate directional velocity or rotational velocity. We only switched to python this year, so if anyone knows the equivalent Java syntax, I could use that too.

Bonus question: If I were to use these states, how could I incorporate error correction? I know Pathplanner is good for that, but it conflicts with our framework.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-01-08T02:44:13.374Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":21,"reads":148,"readers_count":147,"score":134.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":480059,"topic_slug":"how-does-the-wpilib-trajectory-class-work","display_username":"Ethan Grieshop","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62698,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4611 Programmer + Driver"},"post_url":"/t/how-does-the-wpilib-trajectory-class-work/480059/1","custom_user_title":"4611 Programmer + Driver","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3474990,"name":"Justin Buist","username":"Justin_Buist","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/c77e96/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-08T03:39:46.288Z","cooked":"

For a code example I’d go here: https://github.dev/thedropbears/pycrescendo/blob/main/autonomous/base.py

In there you’ll find a calculate_trajectory() that returns a wpimath.trajectory.Trajectory and drive_on_trajectory() which does what I think you’re asking about.

What that does is:

  • Find out where the robot should be at that time in the Trajectory
  • Calculate what the chassis should do to get from where it is (chassis.get_pose()) to where it should be (target_state)
  • Tell the chassis/drivetrain what to do

And with that looping at 50Hz on a well tuned drivetrain it’s wild how well it’ll hold to that trajectory. Simple but super effective.

More or less how a rocket flies too.

Do not use the WPImath trajectory class for swerve on-the-fly pathing. Its generation algorithm is designed for differential drive. Use PathPlanner’s on-the-fly support.

There’s nothing particularly magical about the WPILib command framework, it probably wouldn’t be that hard to integrate command execution into magicbot. I just haven’t done it yet.

I created an issue at magicbot: provide mechanism to run commands · Issue #215 · robotpy/robotpy-wpilib-utilities · GitHub in case someone is interested in working on that.
